defect.para: This Recall applies to AmTran FE buses built from February 19, 1999 through June 14, 1999.

American Transportation Corporation (AmTran) has determined that a defect relating to motor vehicle safety exists in some AmTran FE™ buses. This defect involves the forward handrail (handrail mounted on the windshield side of the step well) on buses with outward opening entrance doors only.

The forward handrail involved in this recall is mounted to the bus at three points (refer to Figure 1 and Figure 2). There are two "U" shaped brackets mounting the handrail to the side of the step well near the entrance door and one flange/cup assembly mounted to the floor near the engine cover. Some of the units in this recall may have been built with the flange/cup assembly (refer to Figure 3) mounted too close to the engine cover. Certain small objects may be caught in this area such as coat tie strings with drawstring clips or other objects attached. Should this happen, and the driver does not properly observe the person exiting the bus, the person may exit the bus with the string caught between the engine cover and the flange/cup assembly. The door may be closed and the bus moved causing possible injury or death to the passenger exiting the bus.
Figure 1 was taken from behind the door opening, and looking into the door entrance. This photo shows the outward opening doors and the location of the handrail.
Figure 2 was taken from the first seat behind the entrance door looking down into the step well. This photo shows all three mounting locations of the handrail and its shape.

Figure 3 was taken at floor level looking toward the front of the bus. This photo shows the flange/cup assembly mounted to the floor adjacent to the engine cover. This is the area that the nut with string must be dragged to determine if the bus needs repair as stated in the INSPECTION procedure.
Owners are being notified of this recall and have been directed to contact an AmTran FE™ dealer to make arrangements for inspection and remedy of the defect.

svcproc.title: INSPECTION
svcproc.para: Review Figure 1 and Figure 2 to make sure that the unit has the handrail involved in this recall. If the handrail in the bus does not match the one illustrated in Figures 1 and 2, return the "AUTHORIZATION FOR RECALL SERVICE" card making sure that box #1 (Inspected - No corrections necessary) is checked.
If the handrail in the bus matches the one illustrated in Figures 1 and 2, proceed with the following inspection procedure.

Inspection of this defect requires dragging a 1/2" hex nut (3/4" across the flats) attached to a 36" long piece of 1/8" cotton string between the engine cover and the flange/cup assembly which is mounted to the floor (refer to Figure 3).

If the nut passes through the opening without catching, the bus does not require repair. Please install the Campaign Identification Label (see instructions below), and complete and return the "AUTHORIZATION FOR RECALL SERVICE" card making sure that box #1 (Inspected - No corrections necessary) is checked.
If the nut catches between the engine cover and the flange/cup assembly, follow the following repair procedure.

step1.para: Remove the four screws that attach the flange/cup assembly to the floor. Move the flange/cup assembly by rotating the handrail to provide a minimum of one (1) inch clearance between the engine cover and the tube portion of the flange/cup assembly. Drill new holes as required using an 11/64 size drill. Re-install the four screws securing the flange/cup assembly to the floor. If there are any exposed holes left empty from the original screw locations, install #12 x 1 1/4-inch pan head zinc plated screws to fill the holes.
Install Campaign Identification Label (see instructions below).
Complete and return the owners' postage-paid "AUTHORIZATION FOR RECALL SERVICE" card making sure that box #2 (Corrections made) is checked.

partsinfo.para: Because the movement of the flange/cup assembly may result in unknown number of exposed holes, the purchase of the screws to plug the exposed holes should be added to the recall claim.

entry.para: Screw #12 x 1 1/4-inch long pan head zinc plated

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified from your dealer location.

The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired within 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.

In order to avoid having to replace an owner's vehicle or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair his or her vehicle as soon as possible.
